revision.comment: Para1, "low-wing" Development para 2, "only much" "50%" para 3, "lifespan" "frontline" deleted "a" para 4, "rollout" Design para 1, "by" para 2, "allround" para 3, "only by" SUI, "eight"
revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name= PC-21 |image= pilatus pc-21 hb-hzc lands arp.jpg |caption= The PC-21 demonstrator lands at [[RIAT]] 2008, [[England]]. }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type= Advanced [[Trainer aircraft]] |manufacturer= [[Pilatus Aircraft]] |designer= Pilatus Aircraft |first flight= 1 July 2002 |introduced= April 2008 |retired= |status=Active service |primary user= [[Swiss Air Force]] |more users= [[Republic of Singapore Air Force]]
[[United Arab Emirates Air Force]]
[[Royal Saudi Air Force]] |produced= 2002–present |number built= 131+ |unit cost= |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Pilatus PC-21''' is a single-[[turboprop]], low-wing swept monoplane advanced [[Trainer (aircraft)|trainer]] with a stepped tandem cockpit manufactured by [[Pilatus Aircraft]] of [[Switzerland]]. ==Development== In November 1997, Pilatus flew a modified [[Pilatus PC-7|PC-7 Mk.II]] in order to test improvements for a prospective next generation turboprop trainer. As a result of these tests, Pilatus elected to fund the development of a new training system in November 1998; development of the new trainer, designated as the ''PC-21'', formally started in January 1999. The PC-21 would be developed and certified as a completely new training system, aimed at meeting future military customers' specifications in terms of capability and life-cycle costs for the next three decades. A key aim for the PC-21 was to allow jet aircraft pilots to perform the majority of the training using the type, converting to jet-powered types only much later than typical contemporary practice, allowing operators to make substantial savings; in order to achieve this aim, the new trainer was required to have an expanded performance envelope in terms of [[aerodynamic]]s, cockpit equipment, flexibility, and ease of maintenance.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/switzerland-special-pilatus-the-success-story-222274/ "Switzerland special: Pilatus the success story."] ''Flight International'', 17 March 2008.[http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/#39 "The NextGen Trainer."] ''Pilatus Aircraft'', Retrieved: 22 March 2016.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pc-21-set-to-revolutionise-training-for-air-forces-151905/ "PC-21 set to revolutionise training for air forces."] ''Flight International'', 22 July 2002. In May 2002, Pilatus announced that it aimed for the PC-21 to capture 50 % of the global trainer aircraft market between 2005 and 2030.Wastnage, Justin. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-aims-for-half-of-trainer-sales-with-pc-21-147384/ "Pilatus aims for half of trainer sales with PC-21."] ''Flight International'', 7 May 2002. From the start of the aircraft's development, Pilatus aimed for the type to have a predictable cost profile over its full lifespan. To meet this goal, the firm chose to incorporate modern materials, an innovative design concept, and full-scale [[fatigue (material)|fatigue]] analysis. Additionally, accompanying the aircraft itself are integrated training systems to meet the pilot's needs; the full package offered by Pilatus includes synthetic training devices, computer-based training, and classroom instruction. As a result of greater training effectiveness, pilots can graduate with fewer total training hours, reaching the frontline faster and at lower cost. In addition to pilots, various prospective aircrew, such as navigators, weapons officers, and electronic warfare operators, can be trained using the type's embedded simulation/emulation system. On 30 April 2002, the rollout of the first PC-21 prototype was performed at Pilatus' factory in Stans, [[Switzerland]]; this aircraft conducted its first flight on 1 July of the same year.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-flies-pc-21-and-aims-for-certification-in-20-150856/ "Pilatus flies PC-21 and aims for certification in 2004."] ''Flight International'', 9 July 2002. In May 2003, Pilatus management formally green-lit the program to proceed to full development. On 7 June 2004, a second PC-21 prototype, the construction of which having been delayed to incorporate improvements learnt from assembling the first, made its maiden flight. In December 2004, Switzerland's [[Federal Office for Civil Aviation of Switzerland|Federal Office for Civil Aviation]] granted [[type certificate|type certification]] for the PC-21; civil certification was attained despite it being a military aircraft as this permitted civil maintenance procedures to be used as well as allowing the aircraft to be supplied under private finance arrangements. Individual Swiss military certification for equipment such as ejection seats has been applied as necessary.Collins, Peter. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/flight-test-pilatus-pc-21-fast-learner-319516/ "FLIGHT TEST: Pilatus PC-21 – Fast learner."] ''Flight International'', 2 December 2008. On 13 January 2005, the second of the two development aircraft crashed in [[Buochs]], Switzerland while conducting an aerobatic training flight; the accident resulted in the death of the pilot as well as injuring another person on the ground.Wastnage, Justin. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/test-pilot-killed-in-pc-21-accident-192584/ "Test pilot killed in PC-21 accident."] ''Flight International'', 18 January 2005. In response to the incident, all PC-21 prototypes were grounded until 1 February 2005, by which point Swiss authorities had established that there was no sign of technical malfunction.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pc-21-grounding-lifted-after-crash-193289/ "PC-21 grounding lifted after crash."] ''Flight International'', 1 February 2005. In August 2006, it was announced that crash investigators had concluded that pilot error had been to blame for the accident in January 2005.Wastnage, Justin. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/january-2005-crash-of-prototype-pilatus-pc-21-attrib-208678/ "January 2005 crash of prototype Pilatus PC-21 attributed to pilot error in official crash report."] ''Flight International'', 25 August 2006. In late August 2005, the first pre-series production PC-21 performed its maiden flight.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/swiss-air-force-poised-to-acquire-six-pc-21s-201506/ "Swiss air force poised to acquire six PC-21s."] ''Flight International'', 13 September 2005. ==Design== [[File:Frola ? 16983 1243165361 (5719962279).jpg|thumb|A PC-21 on static display, 2009]] The Pilatus PC-21 is an advanced single-engine trainer aircraft; it is often referred to by Pilatus as being the "Twenty-first Century Trainer". The type can be applied for various training capacities, including basic flying training, advanced flight training, full mission management training, and embedded simulation/emulation. In order to perform these functions, the aircraft possesses a powerful, flexible, and cost-effective integrated training system; providing sufficient ease of use for inexperienced pilots while posing greater challenge to advanced pilots. According to Pilatus, upon product launch, the PC-21 possessed "superior aerodynamic performance when compared with any other turboprop trainer on the market". The aircraft features a [[tandem]]-seating arrangement (student in-front/instructor behind) in a [[bird strike]]-resistant glass [[Aircraft canopy|canopy]] with allround vision. The cabin, which is pressurized, is equipped with an [[Oxygen concentrator#Military uses|On-Board Oxygen Generation System]] (OBOGS), [[air conditioning]], and [[Martin-Baker]] CH16C [[Ejection seat#Zero-zero ejection seat|Zero-Zero ejector seats]].[http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/00-def/main/scripts/ckfinder/userfiles/files/Downloads/Brochures/Pilatus%20Aircraft%20Ltd%20-%20PC-21%20Brochure.pdf "PC-21: 21st Century Training for 21st Century Air Forces."] ''Pilatus Aircraft'', Retrieved: 23 March 2016. The flight controls, which are fully balanced and harmonized, are optimized for easy of operation and overall effectiveness. An anti-[[g-force|g]] system is also present in order to minimize the effects of high g-forces experienced during tactical training and aerobatic maneuvers. Pilots are able to spend a greater amount of time concentrating on the aircraft's external situation and upon mission data inputs due to an ergonomic design approach, ease-of-use controls, and clear visual/system data displays. In addition, a full [[autopilot]] and civil flight management system are also present. The PC-21 is powered by a single 1,600 [[Horsepower#Shaft horsepower .28shp.29|shaft horse power]] [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6|Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6A-68B]] [[turboprop]] engine, which drives a five-bladed [[graphite]] [[Hartzell]] [[scimitar propeller]] on the aircraft's nose; it has been claimed by Pilatus that the PC-21 possesses speed and climb rates previously normally performed only by jet-powered aircraft. It is also fitted with a high-speed profile wing, rated for maneuvers up to 8 [[g-force|g]], complete with [[hydraulic|hyraulically]]-assisted [[aileron]]s and [[Spoiler (aeronautics)|spoilers]] which enable the execution of fighter-like rates of roll and other maneuvers. In order to make the aircraft easy to fly at low speeds, crucial to the advanced trainer role, the PC-21 is furnished with a digital power management system and the [[tailplane|horizontal stabilizer]] is equipped with an automatic [[Aircraft principal axes#Vertical axis .28yaw.29|yaw]] compensator/suppression system to compensate for engine power and speed changes.[http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/#40 "Aircraft Data."] ''Pilatus Aircraft'', Retrieved: 22 March 2016. [[File:PC-21 (5089438327).jpg|thumb|left|Underside of a PC-21 in-flight]] A key feature of the PC-21 is the embedded simulation and training suite, which provides cross-platform cockpit emulation, weapons simulation, stores management system, simulated radar and [[electronic warfare]], a tactical situation display, and [[data link]] functionality.Penny, Stewart. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-unveils-simulation-system-for-pc-21-trainer-166282/ "Pilatus unveils simulation system for PC-21 trainer."] ''Flight International'', 3 June 2003. Key to this is the Mission Support System (MSS), which comprises the Mission Planning System (MPS) and Mission Debriefing System (MBS); data can be loaded and unloaded from these, which is compatible with ground-based stations for pre-flight configuration or post-mission analysis. The integrated mission computer is of an [[open architecture]], allowing for third-party modifications and upgrades to take place; software can also be customized to conform to customer preferences.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-to-adapt-pc-21-210564/ "Pilatus to adapt PC-21."] ''Flight International'', 14 November 2006. Critical and non-critical software are also deliberately separated. The cockpit of the PC-21 features a high level of systems integration and conforms to modern avionics standards. The systems of the forward and rear cockpits can be 'de-coupled' between the student and instructor; the instructor may exercise real-time manipulation of the student's displays, sensor performance, and system modes such as to create synthetic air-to-air radar targets, artificial non-safety critical system failures, and controlled data degradation. The aircraft's fully digital [[glass cockpit]] features three large colour [[liquid crystal display]]s (LCD), one performing as the primary flight display (PFD) and two multi-function displays (MFDs) for system/mission management, in addition to CMC Electronics-provided [[head-up display]]s (HUD) for both the pilot and instructor.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/integrated-cockpit-is-pillar-of-new-product-strategy-199539/ "Integrated cockpit is pillar of new product strategy."] ''Flight International'', 15 June 2005. The trim gauge is the only analogue dial in the cockpit. For control simplicity, a [[Hands on Throttle and Stick]] (HOTAS) control philosophy has been followed. Both the display and control systems present also resemble their counterparts used upon modern front-line combat aircraft for greater realism during training; and can be further customized in order to be more representative of specific combat aircraft.[http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/#41 "A Cockpit for Maximum Training Value."] ''Pilatus Aircraft'', Retrieved: 22 March 2016. The multi-sensor navigation system is capable of operating under a military tactical mode as well as a civil navigation mode. ==Operational history== [[File:Pilatus PC-21, Pilatus AN1852215.jpg|thumb|A PC-21 landing at [[RAF Fairford]], [[Gloucestershire]], [[England]], 2010]] In the Armament Program 2006, the [[Federal Assembly (Switzerland)|Swiss Parliament]] approved an initial purchase of the PC-21 for the [[Swiss Air Force]]. By April 2008, four PC-21 have been taken over by the Swiss Air Force following the passing of acceptance trials, and flight operations were set to start in July that year.{{cite press release| url=http://www.news.admin.ch/message/index.html?lang=en&msg-id=18550 |title= Acceptance of the first four Pilatus PC-21 by armasuisse |publisher=Swiss Federation |accessdate=29 April 2010}} In December 2010, the Swiss Air Force placed an order for another two aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://www.defpro.com/news/details/20711/|title=Pilatus Wins PC-21 Follow-up Order From the Swiss Air Force|last=Stans|date=17 December 2010|publisher=Pilatus Aircraft|accessdate=22 June 2013|archiveurl=http://archive.is/viMH|archivedate=29 July 2012}}Trimble, Stephen. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-receives-follow-on-pc-21-trainer-order-from-351075/ "Pilatus receives follow-on PC-21 trainer order from Swiss air force."] ''Flight International'', 17 December 2010. In November 2006, the [[Republic of Singapore Air Force]] (RSAF) awarded a service contract to Lockheed Martin Simulation, Training and Support (LMSTS) to deliver 19 PC-21 aircraft, to support the RSAF's Basic Wings training course in [[RAAF Base Pearce|Pearce]], [[Australia]] under a [[public–private partnership]] (PPP) arrangement, replacing the [[SIAI-Marchetti S.211]].[http://www.defense-aerospace.com/articles-view/release/3/75231/singapore-order-to-launch-pilatus-pc_21-production.html "PC-21s to Replace S211s for RSAF's Basic Wings Training."] ''defense-aerospace'', 3 November 2006.Wastnage, Justin. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-martin-pilatus-team-win-singapore-trainer-deal-launch-of-pc-21-production-now-210372/ "Lockheed Martin Pilatus team win Singapore trainer deal, launch of PC-21 production now possible."] ''Flight International'', 3 November 2006. Singapore was the first export customer for the PC-21.David, Donald. [https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/defense/2016-02-14/australia-joins-singapore-pc-21-club "Australia Joins Singapore in the PC-21 Club."] ''AIN Online'', 14 February 2016. On 21 January 2008, the first RSAF PC-21 completed its flight test prior to being accepted into service.{{cite press release |url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2008/feb/15feb08_nr2.html |title= RSAF Pilatus PC-21 Makes its Maiden Flight |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)|Ministry of Defence]] (MINDEF) |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=29 April 2010}}Warwick, Graham.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/picture-pilatus-flies-first-pc-21-for-singapore-221670/ "PICTURE: Pilatus flies first PC-21 for Singapore."] ''Flight International'', 19 February 2008. On 13 July 2008, the type began to provide the RSAF with basic flying training, by which point a further six aircraft had been delivered.{{cite press release |url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2008/jul/13jul08_nr.html |title= Basic Flying Training on the Pilatus PC-21 Aircraft Trainer Commences |publisher=''MINDEF'' |date=13 July 2008 |accessdate=29 April 2010}} During the 2009 [[Dubai Airshow]], the [[United Arab Emirates]] announced an order of 25 PC-21 trainers for the [[United Arab Emirates Air Force]] (UAEAF) to replace their aging fleet of [[Pilatus PC-7]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/11/17/335112/dubai-09-uae-signs-deal-for-25-pc-21-trainers.html|title=Dubai 09: UAE signs deal for 25 PC-21 trainers|last=Craig|first=Hoyle|date=17 November 2009|publisher=[[Flightglobal.com|Flight Global]]|accessdate=30 September 2012}} On 22 November 2010, the UAEAF's first PC-21 performed its maiden flight.{{cite magazine|date=February 2011|title=UAE's first PC-21 flown|magazine=[[Air Forces Monthly]]|publisher=[[Key Publishing|Key Publishing Ltd]]|issue= 274|page=26|issn=0955-7091}}Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pictures-uaes-first-pc-21-makes-flight-debut-350071/ "PICTURES: UAE's first PC-21 makes flight debut."] ''Flight International'', 23 November 2010. In July 2012, it was announced that the [[Qatar Air Force]] had placed an order for a complete pilot training system from Pilatus centering upon the PC-21. The package included ground-based training devices, logistical support and maintenance in addition to 24 PC-21 aircraft.Pocock, Chris. [http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/defense/2012-07-27/pilatus-pc-21-scores-another-pilot-training-win-qatar "Pilatus PC-21 Scores Another Pilot Training Win in Qatar."] ''AIN Online'', 27 July 2012.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/first-qatari-pc-21-enters-ground-test-396170/ "First Qatari PC-21 enters ground test."] ''Flight International'', 20 February 2014. On 1 October 2014, the Qatar Air Force formally received its first batch of PC-21 trainers.[http://www.gulf-times.com/story/410667/Emiri-Air-Force-receives-first-batch-of-PC-21-airc "Emiri Air Force receives first batch of PC-21 aircraft."] ''Gulf Times'', 1 October 2014.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/first-pc-21s-head-for-qatar-404299/ "First PC-21s head for Qatar."] ''Flight International'', 30 September 2014. On 23 May 2012, [[Saudi Arabia]] signed a £1.6 billion ($2.5 billion) for a comprehensive next-generation military pilot training system, comprising 22 [[BAE Systems Hawk]] advanced jet trainers in addition to 55 PC-21 trainers.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/saudi-arabia-signs-102-aircraft-military-training-de-372229/ "Saudi Arabia signs 102-aircraft military training deal."] ''Flight International'', 23 May 2012.Trimble, Stephen, [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pilatus-pc-21s-in-package-deal-with-hawks-for-saudi-372004/ "Pilatus PC-21s in package deal with Hawks for Saudi air force."] ''Flight International'', 17 May 2012. In early June 2014, Pilatus commenced delivery of the first six PC-21s to Saudi Arabia;Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/saudi-arabia-gets-first-six-pc-21-trainers-400296/ "Saudi Arabia gets first six PC-21 trainers."] ''Flight International'', 11 June 2014. by the end of 2015, this had risen to 46 PC-21s delivered.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/follow-on-purchase-to-boost-saudi-hawk-renewal-422194/ "Follow-on purchase to boost Saudi Hawk renewal."] ''Flight International'', 19 February 2016. The PC-21 was one of the submissions for the [[Royal Australian Air Force]]'s project AIR 5428, which sought a replacement of its Pilatus PC-9s;Pittaway 2010, p. 20.Waldron, Greg. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-pilatus-hawker-pacific-bid-for-raaf-basic-391266/ "Lockheed, Pilatus, Hawker Pacific bid for RAAF basic trainer deal."] ''Flight International'', 3 October 2013. in September 2015, it was announced that the consortium comprising Lockheed Martin, Pilatus and Hawker Pacific ("Team 21"), had won the bid to provide 49 PC-21s to the Australian Defence Force."Lockheed Martin Wins Air 5428." ''Australian Defence Magazine'', 13 May 2015.Pittaway, Nigel. [http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/training-simulation/2015/09/10/australia-buy-pc-21-trainers-relocate-basic-training/72031512/ "Australia To Buy PC-21 Trainers, Relocate Basic Training."] ''Defense News'', 11 September 2015. Moreover, the PC-21 has been evaluated by the [[Spanish Air Force]], along the [[Beechcraft T-6 Texan II|T-6 Texan II]] and the [[PZL-130 Orlik|PZL-130 Orlik III]], as a possible substitute for its [[ENAER T-35 Pillan]] and [[CASA C-101 Aviojet]] trainer aircraft.{{citation|date=November 2008|title=Evaluación del PC-21 Pilatus como entrenador Elemental/Básico/Avanzado|publisher=[[Revista de Aeronáutica y Astronáutica]]|journal=[[Ejército del Aire de España]]|number= 778|accessdate=19 July 2011}} In August 2015, Pilatus received a contract to deliver nine PC-9Ms to the Royal Jordanian Air Force, but in April 2016 changed the order to eight PC-21s. Deliveries were due to start in January 2017 under the original deal.{{Cite web |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/jordan-amends-pilatus-order-to-take-pc-21-trainers-424048/ |title=Jordan amends Pilatus order to take PC-21 trainers |date=11 April 2016 |publisher=FlightGlobal}} ==Operators== [[File:Pilatus pc-21 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Pair of PC-21s, 2004]] ;{{AUS}} *[[Royal Australian Air Force]]: 49 PC-21 on order, ordered September 2015.{{cite web|title=Lockheed’s "Team 21" finally confirmed as AIR 5428 winning bidder|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/09/lockheeds-team-21-finally-confirmed-as-air-5428-winning-bidder/|website=Australian Aviation|publisher=australianaviation.com.au|accessdate=27 October 2015}} ;{{QAT}} *[[Qatar Emiri Air Force]]: 24 PC-21 on order, ordered July 2012, first delivery scheduled for 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/qatar-signs-deal-for-24-pilatus-pc-21s-374615/|title=Qatar signs deal for 24 Pilatus PC-21s|last=Craig|first=Hoyle|date=23 July 2012|publisher=Flight Global|accessdate=29 September 2012}} ;{{SAU}} *[[Royal Saudi Air Force]]: 55 PC-21 on order, ordered May 2012, first delivery scheduled for 2014. ;{{SIN}} *[[Republic of Singapore Air Force]]: launch customer; operates 19 PC-21 on Basic Wings Course (BWC) as part of a contact for availability, together with Lockheed Martin and Hawker Pacific. ;{{SUI}} *[[Swiss Air Force]] operates eight PC-21s for advanced training, replacing the [[BAE Systems Hawk|BAe Hawk]] which had been retired since 2003. ;{{UAE}} *[[United Arab Emirates Air Force]]: operates 25 PC-21s for advanced training, first flight made on 22 November 2010. ==Specifications (PC-21)== [[File:pilatus.pc-21.fairford2006.arp.jpg|thumb|The Pilatus PC-21; note the stepped tandem cockpit]] {{External media|topic= |width=20% |align=right |video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dUyZJV7zpIU Swiss Air Force PC-12 flight demonstration at the Breitling Sion Airshow 2011] |video2=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PaErmMEMC9Y In-cockpit video of PC-12 takeoff] |video3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BExHVHAL1gc PC-21s at Koor Airport, Qatar]}} {{Aircraft specifications |plane or copter?=plane |jet or prop?=prop |ref= [[Pilatus Aircraft]]{{cite web |url=http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/00-def/main/scripts/ckfinder/userfiles/files/Downloads/Brochures/Pilatus%20Aircraft%20Ltd%20-%20PC-21%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf |title=Pilatus: PC-21 fact sheet |format=PDF |publisher=Pilatus Aircraft Ltd |accessdate=29 April 2010}} |crew=two (student & instructor) |capacity= |length main=11.233 m |length alt=36 ft 11 in |span main=9.108 m |span alt=29 ft 11 in |height main=3.749 m |height alt=12 ft 4 in |area main=15.221 m² |area alt=163.848 ft² |airfoil= |empty weight main=2,270 kg |empty weight alt=5,005 lb |loaded weight main= |loaded weight alt= |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main=3,100 kg (aerobatic) / 4,250 kg (utility) |max takeoff weight alt=6,834 lb (aerobatic) / 9,370 lb (utility) |more general= |engine (prop)= [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6#PT6A|Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6A-68B]] |type of prop= [[Turboprop]] engine |number of props= 1 |power main= 1,200 kW |power alt= 1,600 shp |power original= |max speed main=685 km/h |max speed alt=370 knots, 428 mph |cruise speed main= |cruise speed alt= |never exceed speed main= |never exceed speed alt= |stall speed main=170 km/h |stall speed alt=92 knots, 106.25 mph |stall speed more=gear and flaps up (20 km/h less with flaps and gear down) |range main=1,333 km |range alt=720 nm, 828 miles |ceiling main=11,580 m |ceiling alt=38,000 ft |climb rate main=1,219 m/min |climb rate alt=4,000 ft/min |loading main=208 kg/m² |loading alt=42.7 lb/ft² |thrust/weight= |power/mass main=0.39 kW/kg |power/mass alt=0.23 hp/lb |more performance= * '''g limits:''' + 8.0 g to – 4.0 (aerobatic) / + 5.0 g to – 2.5 g (utility) |armament= *'''[[Hardpoint]]s:''' Provisions provided for 4× under-wing and 1× centerline external store stations, capable of mounting up to {{convert|1150|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of payload of air-to-ground weapons to operate in the [[Counter-insurgency]] role.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} |avionics= }} ==See also== {{Aircontent| |related= *[[Pilatus PC-7]] *[[Pilatus PC-9]] |similar aircraft= *[[Beechcraft T-6 Texan II]] *[[Embraer EMB 314 Super Tucano]] *[[KAI KT-1]] *[[TAI Hürkuş]] |sequence= |lists= |see also= }} ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} *{{Cite journal |last=Pittaway |first=Nigel |title=ADF pilot training under contract |journal=Defence Today |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=20–21 |publisher=Strike Publications |location=Amberley |date=March 2010 |issn=1447-0446 }} {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category|Pilatus PC-21}} *[http://www.pilatus-aircraft.com/#39 Pilatus PC-21 Official Site] {{Pilatus aircraft}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pilatus Pc-21}} [[Category:Pilatus aircraft|PC-21]] [[Category:Swiss military trainer aircraft 2000–2009]] [[Category:Single-engined tractor aircraft]] [[Category:Low-wing aircraft]] [[Category:Turboprop aircraft]]
